tool_input.content:
import { Pool } from 'pg'

const pool = new Pool({
  connectionString: process.env.DATABASE_URL,
})

export { pool }

export interface Comment {
  id: number
  post_slug: string
  clerk_user_id: string
  username: string
  content: string
  parent_id: number | null
  created_at: string
  updated_at: string
  like_count?: number
  user_has_liked?: boolean
  replies?: Comment[]
}

export interface CommentLike {
  id: number
  comment_id: number
  clerk_user_id: string
  created_at: string
}

results:
Based on the search results, here's what I found about Clerk appearance elements for userButton popover styling in 2025:

## Clerk UserButton Popover Styling Elements

Clerk's appearance property allows you to share styles across every component or individually style specific elements through fine-grained theme overrides.

### Key UserButton Styling Elements

The userButton appearance can be customized with specific element classes including `userButtonAvatarBox` for custom width and height, `userButtonPopoverCard` for the popover card background, and `userButtonPopoverActionButton` for action button text colors.

Common Clerk elements that can be styled include `.cl-userButtonPopoverCard` and `.cl-organizationSwitcherPopoverCard` which can be targeted with rounded borders, input backgrounds, and other styles.

### Methods for Styling

For full control over the appearance of Clerk components, you can target underlying elements using their CSS classes by inspecting the HTML of the component.

Elements can be styled with inline CSS objects directly in the appearance prop, or you can use global CSS by targeting specific classes like `cl-formButtonPrimary` for primary buttons.

### Appearance Configuration Options

Components can be customized by passing an object of variables to the variables property of the appearance prop. Clerk also exposes native CSS variables that can be defined directly in your application's stylesheet.

Themes can be applied to all instances of a Clerk component by passing the component to the appearance prop of the ClerkProvider, with the component name as a key.

### Layout and Animation Options

The layout prop includes options like shimmer animation for avatars in UserButton and OrganizationSwitcher components, which defaults to true.

### Custom Menu Items

UserButton supports custom menu items through `<UserButton.Action>` for triggering actions and `<UserButton.Link>` for navigation.

The styling system supports modern CSS features and provides flexibility through themes, variables, CSS classes, and inline styles to customize the UserButton popover and other Clerk components according to your design needs.

Breaking Shit & Fixing It

Infrastructure as Code when you barely know how to code.

What This Actually Is My first homelab setup, documented as I learn

This is my first homelab running on a Minisforum UN100. I'm learning infrastructure by building it, breaking it, and documenting what might actually work. Packer for VM images, Vagrant for management, tmux for automation, and Claude Code as my agentic OS.

Each post covers real problems I've hit and the actual solutions that worked. No theory, no best practices from people who've never touched production - just what happens when you learn DevOps by doing it.

Cheers, WillyV3

tool_response.stdout:
WillyV3@Home

Breaking Shit & Fixing It

Infrastructure as Code when you barely know how to code.

What This Actually Is
My first homelab setup, documented as I learn

This is my first homelab running on a Minisforum UN100. I'm learning infrastructure by building it, breaking it, and documenting what might actually work. Packer for VM images, Vagrant for management, tmux for automation, and Claude Code as my agentic OS.

Each post covers real problems I've hit and the actual solutions that worked. No theory, no best practices from people who've never touched production - just what happens when you learn DevOps by doing it.

Cheers, WillyV3

Recent Posts

- Implement sitemap.xml and RSS feed generation
- Add robots.txt for SEO
- Update gitignore to exclude logs and observability files
- Fix comment like toggle system for better UX
- Apply Clerk theming fixes for proper UI consistency
- Optimize build configuration and lint issues

🤖 Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
)"

This is a [Next.js](https://nextjs.org) project bootstrapped with [`create-next-app`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/cli/create-next-app).

## Getting Started

First, run the development server:

```bash
npm run dev
# or
yarn dev
# or
pnpm dev
# or
bun dev
```

Open [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000) with your browser to see the result.

You can start editing the page by modifying `app/page.tsx`. The page auto-updates as you edit the file.

This project uses [`next/font`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/optimizing/fonts) to automatically optimize and load [Geist](https://vercel.com/font), a new font family for Vercel.

## Learn More

To learn more about Next.js, take a look at the following resources:

- [Next.js Documentation](https://nextjs.org/docs) - learn about Next.js features and API.
- [Learn Next.js](https://nextjs.org/learn) - an interactive Next.js tutorial.

You can check out [the Next.js GitHub repository](https://github.com/vercel/next.js) - your feedback and contributions are welcome!

## Deploy on Vercel

The easiest way to deploy your Next.js app is to use the [Vercel Platform](https://vercel.com/new?utm_medium=default-template&filter=next.js&utm_source=create-next-app&utm_campaign=create-next-app-readme) from the creators of Next.js.

Check out our [Next.js deployment documentation](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/deploying) for more details.

# WillyV3's Homelab Blog

> Infrastructure as Code when you barely know how to code. Real failures, real solutions.

A Next.js 15 blog with MDX support, Clerk authentication, Neon PostgreSQL comments, and doom-64 retro gaming theme.

## Features

- 🎮 **doom-64 theme** - Retro gaming aesthetic with shadcn/ui components
- 📝 **MDX blog posts** - Write rich content with React components
- 💬 **Comments system** - Authenticated comments with likes via Clerk + Neon
- 🔍 **SEO optimized** - Comprehensive metadata, sitemap, RSS feed
- 🚀 **Production ready** - Built with Next.js 15, TypeScript, Tailwind v4

## Adding Blog Posts with Claude Code

This blog is designed to work seamlessly with Claude Code. To add new blog posts:

### Method 1: Direct Command
```bash
claude "Add a new blog post about [topic]"
```

### Method 2: Detailed Instructions
```bash
claude "Create a new blog post:
- Title: Your Post Title
- Topic: Brief description
- Include code examples, images, or specific sections
- Add appropriate tags and metadata"
```

### Blog Post Structure
Claude Code will automatically:
- Create a new `.mdx` file in `/src/content/blog/`
- Generate proper frontmatter with title, date, excerpt, tags
- Structure content with headings, code blocks, and components
- Optimize for SEO with proper metadata

### Example Blog Post Request
```bash
claude "Write a blog post about setting up a Kubernetes cluster on Raspberry Pi. Include:
- Hardware requirements
- Installation steps with code
- Common troubleshooting issues
- Performance benchmarks
Tag it with: kubernetes, raspberry-pi, homelab"
```

## Development

```bash
# Install dependencies
npm install

# Run development server
npm run dev

# Build for production
npm run build

# Start production server
npm start
```

## Environment Variables

Create a `.env.local` file:

```env
# Clerk Authentication
NEXT_PUBLIC_CLERK_PUBLISHABLE_KEY=pk_test_...
CLERK_SECRET_KEY=sk_test_...

# Neon PostgreSQL
DATABASE_URL=postgresql://...
```

## Tech Stack

- **Framework**: Next.js 15 with App Router
- **Styling**: Tailwind CSS v4 + shadcn/ui (doom-64 theme)
- **Content**: MDX with gray-matter frontmatter
- **Auth**: Clerk
- **Database**: Neon PostgreSQL
- **Deployment**: Vercel-ready

## Repository

https://github.com/williavs/homelab-blog

---

Built with Claude Code 🤖
